interlinear-text.item: ELA A Rich Man and His Beautiful Daughter [3]

phrase.item: There was a man who played with gold and silver.
He was very rich, you know?
Very wealthy.
He also had a garden, the Garden of Firdaws, a paradise
The Garden of Firdaws was his
In that garden there was a young boy in charge.
He was given two small pieces of bread for the whole day.

Whenever he had those two pieces of bread, he would break them and wouldn't even eat even the crumbs in case someone should show up, from any side of the road. If two people came he would break the bread and share it with them.
But he wouldn't eat the crumbs by himself.
Time passed like that and [one day]
There wasn't anyone.
You see to that level. he waited but nobody crossed by, he got really hungry.
Then there was a dog there, and he called the dog over.
The dog came in front of him. He broke the bread, gave half to the dog and ate the other half.
He ate it, but Hazrat Ali didn't know he [boy] is not aware of god.
Hazrat Ali was behind him and said, "Your owner, the man who had gold and silver and was playing with them-- in fact when the owner was dreaming that
first time, they put him in the fire [to kill him] and Hazrat Ali took him out.
Again, they would throw him in the fire and Hazrat Ali would take him out. They put him in a third time and
when he was taken out he [the owner] said, "I accept the faith of Muhammad.
I don't need a garden or desert, only one daughter."
His daughter was extremely beautiful.
"I don't need anything else.
I will start praying and fasting.
" That is how dedication to god is.
Then [the boy] said, " Oh, Hazrat Ali!
If any time you go there [to the owner's house], bring his daughter with you."
Hazrat Ali came to his house and [the owner] said,
"Oh Hazrat Ali! The garden is yours, all yours, and all I have is a daughter, she is also yours.
Whether you throw her onto a boulder or in river, it's up to you."
Hazrat Ali brought her to the boy. You see, just from the bread,
he even didn't eat the crumbs by himself, but with someone else.
Bread has such value and power.
[Hazrat Ali] gave her to him.
Later, the boy said, "This garden is yours, I just needed this girl."
Hazrat Ali said, "The garden is also yours, I don't need it."
Why would Hazrat Ali need the garden? He said, "Both, garden and wife are yours, live your life."
He continued living!
